title: 106_hr263
content: The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes an excise tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payments in factoring transactions, as outlined in Chapter 55 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardships. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" allows for the transfer of structured settlement payments in cases of extraordinary, unanticipated, and imminent needs, as determined by a court or administrative authority. The act defines a structured settlement as an arrangement for periodic payments of damages or compensation that are excluded from gross income. The structured settlement allows for the transfer of periodic payments of damages or compensation that are excludable from gross income under specific conditions. The term 'structured settlement payment rights' refers to the rights to receive payments under a structured settlement, while a 'structured settlement factoring transaction' involves the transfer of these payment rights. The term 'structured settlement payment rights' refers to the rights to receive payments under a structured settlement. A 'structured settlement factoring transaction' involves the transfer of these payment rights for consideration. The 'factoring discount' is the excess amount paid by the acquirer compared to the total amount of structured settlement payments acquired. The term 'relevant court or administrative authority' refers to the court or administrative body with jurisdiction over the underlying action resolved by a structured settlement, or in the absence of a legal action, the court or administrative body overseeing the matter. The relevant court or administrative authority with jurisdiction over the underlying action resolved by a structured settlement, or in the absence of a legal action, the court or administrative body overseeing the matter. Coordination with other provisions such as sections 72, 130, and 461(h) must be satisfied at the time the structured settlement was entered into. The structured settlement recipient's residence is important. The occurrence of a structured settlement factoring transaction should not affect the application of certain provisions if requirements of sections 72, 130, and 461(h) were met at the time of the settlement. The Secretary can create regulations to clarify the treatment of amounts received in such transactions. The Secretary can create regulations to clarify the treatment of amounts received in structured settlement factoring transactions. SEC. 6050T. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS REGARDING STRUCTURED SETTLEMENT FACTORING TRANSACTIONS. SEC. 6050T requires reporting for structured settlement factoring transactions. In these transactions, the person making the structured settlement payments must provide returns and statements to the acquirer of the payment rights as per section 6041 or under tax regulations. The person making structured settlement payments must report to the acquirer of payment rights in structured settlement factoring transactions, as per section 6050T. This reporting requirement replaces other provisions and withholding rules under section 3405. The reporting obligations of the person making structured settlement payments in structured settlement factoring transactions are defined. Withholding rules under section 3405 do not apply in these transactions. The term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights' includes persons described in section 7701(a)(1). Clerical amendments are made to the Code. The table of sections for subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions. These amendments apply to transactions occurring after the enactment of the Act.
